logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text:
Are you high??? Selling someone a cake? Refusing to sell some a cake because it is for
a gay wedding is no different from selling someone a cake because it is for a mixed race
wedding or a Muslim wedding or any other kind of wedding. IT IS DISCRIMINATION!
Would you be ok with my store refusing to sell you something because you are an
idol worshipping immoral Catholic and it might be used in one of your heathen First
Communion celebrations? You know when those Catholics worship Mary and little
pieces of bread don’t you?

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, oh please, it's just a cake. If you can't handle a little 'discrimination' over a cake, how are you going to handle the real world? And who said anything about idol worshipping? You're just looking for a fight, aren't you? 🙄

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: Well, @doing_my_best24, you're right about one thing - it is discrimination. But let's not forget, the baker has the right to refuse service if it goes against their beliefs. It's not like they're refusing to serve the couple because of their race or religion. They're refusing to create a specific product for a specific event. It's a slippery slope when we start forcing people to create things that go against their beliefs. And @QueenOfChaos, don't dismiss it as 'just a cake'. It's a symbol of something much bigger. And no, I don't think the world is going to end if someone can't get a cake from a specific baker. But I also don't think we should be forcing people to do things that go against their beliefs. That's not freedom, that's tyranny.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, oh please, spare me the'slippery slope' argument. It's the same tired rhetoric used to justify every form of discrimination. If we let gays marry, next thing you know, people will be marrying their dogs! Give me a break. And yes, it is just a cake. It's not a symbol of some grand ideology, it's a dessert. If a baker doesn't want to make a cake for a gay wedding, they can find another job. It's not like they're being forced to perform a religious ritual against their will. They're just being asked to do their job. And don't give me that 'tyranny' nonsense. The real tyranny is when people use their beliefs to discriminate against others.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're missing the point. It's not about the cake, it's about the principle. If we allow businesses to refuse service based on who the customer is or what the product is for, where does it stop? Next thing you know, someone could refuse to sell a black couple a house because they don't want to live next to them. And yes, it is a slippery slope. Just because you don't see the danger now doesn't mean it's not there. And @GoldenYears66, while I understand your perspective, I don't agree that beliefs should be used to discriminate. If a baker doesn't want to make a cake for a gay wedding, they can simply say they're booked or don't have the capacity. They don't need to bring their personal beliefs into it. It's a business, not a pulpit.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, oh, here we go with the'slippery slope' again. You're comparing apples to oranges. Refusing to sell a house to someone because of their race is a whole different ball game than refusing to make a cake for a gay wedding. One is blatant racism, the other is a baker exercising their right to not participate in something they disagree with. And please, don't give me that 'it's a business, not a pulpit' nonsense. If a baker doesn't want to make a cake for a gay wedding, that's their prerogative. They're not obligated to cater to every single event or cause. And if you can't handle that, maybe you should bake your own damn cake. 🤷‍♀️

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're right that the situations are different, but the principle is the same - refusing service based on who the customer is. And yes, racism is a more severe form of discrimination, but that doesn't mean we should ignore other forms of it. If we start allowing businesses to pick and choose who they serve based on personal beliefs, it opens the door for all kinds of discrimination. And no, a baker isn

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're missing the forest for the trees. It's not about the cake, it's about the precedent. If we allow businesses to refuse service based on personal beliefs, we're opening a can of worms. Today it's a baker refusing a gay wedding, tomorrow it's a doctor refusing to treat a trans patient, and the day after that, it's a landlord refusing to rent to a single mother. It's a slippery slope, and you're just too stubborn to see it. And don't give me that it's just a cake nonsense. It's not just a cake, it's a symbol of acceptance and equality. If a baker can't handle that, maybe they should find a different line of work. 🤷‍♂️

logs.name: WiseOwl71
doing_my_best24
logs.text:
@WiseOwl71, you're absolutely right. Nuance is key here. The baker's refusal is indeed a form of discrimination, and while it's not the same as racial discrimination, it's still harmful. And you're spot on about the consequences - if a baker chooses to refuse service, they should be prepared to face the backlash, including potential loss of business. That's a fair trade-off for exercising their personal beliefs in a public setting.

@QueenOfChaos, I understand where you're coming from, but I think we can agree that the 'it's just a cake' argument doesn't hold much water. It's not just about the cake, it's about the message it sends. And @TechGuru88, you're right about the slippery slope, but I think we can also agree

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text:
@doing_my_best24, I appreciate your thoughtful response. It's refreshing to see someone willing to engage with nuance. However, I must push back on one point. You said, That's a fair trade-off for exercising their personal beliefs in a public setting. I disagree. The baker's personal beliefs don't give them the right to discriminate against others. If they can't serve a customer without discriminating, perhaps they should reconsider their business model. After all, a business that serves everyone is a business that can grow and thrive.

@TechGuru88, you're right that we need to consider the precedent, but let's not forget that the law is not a static thing. It evolves with society. We've seen this with racial discrimination, and we can see

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, you're right that the law evolves, but it's not always in the right direction. Look at the recent rollbacks on voting rights, for instance. And while I agree that a business that serves everyone can grow and thrive, that's not the point. The baker isn't refusing service because they think it's bad for business, they're doing it because of their personal beliefs. And if we start allowing businesses to refuse service

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, oh please, spare me the 'nuance' lecture. You're just trying to sound smart while dancing around the fact that this is plain and simple discrimination. And @doing_my_best24, don't give me that 'it's not just about the cake' nonsense. It's literally just about the cake. If you don't like the baker's beliefs, don't buy their cake. It's that simple. And @TechGuru88, you're right about the slippery slope. Next thing you know, we'll have bakers refusing to make cakes for atheists because they believe in God. Oh wait, that's already

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're missing the point. It's not just about the cake, it's about the message it sends. If a baker refuses to make a cake for a same-sex wedding, they're saying that LGBTQ+ people are less than. That's not just discrimination, that's hate. And don't give me that don't buy their cake nonsense. That's like telling a black person in the 60s to just not sit at the front of the bus. It's not that simple. We need to stand up for what's right, even if it makes some people uncomfortable. And @TechGuru88, you're right about the slippery slope, but let's not forget that the law is supposed to protect everyone, not just the majority. If we start allowing businesses to refuse service based on personal beliefs, where does it end? Do we let doctors refuse to treat LGBTQ+ patients? Do we let landlords refuse to rent to interracial couples? No,

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, your passion is commendable, but let's not oversimplify the issue. It's not just about the cake, and it's not just about discrimination. It's about the message it sends to the community. As @GoldenYears66 pointed out, refusing service to a same-sex couple isn't just about the cake, it's about validating or invalidating their love and relationship. And that's where the line is drawn. A business has the right to refuse service, but not based on personal beliefs that demean or devalue others. As for your slippery slope argument, @TechGuru88, yes, we must be cautious, but we also must remember that the law is meant to protect the vulnerable, not the majority.
